ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I developed Italian language speaking skills, increased my vocabulary and grasp of Italian grammar. I also learned more about Italian culture.
I learned Italian and about Italy's culture.
a development of my Italian skills (reading, writing, speaking, and grammar)
I learned and expanded upon my knowledge of Italian from 110. You learn about new vocab, subjunctive and conditional tenses, as well as watch a few movies and read a few short stories.
I learned more Italian
I learned the future, conditional and past tenses of Italian. In addition, I was able to practice speaking, while developing an understanding for idiomatic terms.
Italian conversational skills and grammar.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course is tremendously well organized and the time in class is used with great efficiency. Every minute is used to reinforce vocabulary and grammar lessons to great effect.
I think Italian is taught very well here, but I think language courses are inherently worse online. I also think the grading could have been a little less strict.

strengths: moves at a good pace, great professor, very engaging during class time
weaknesses: none

Strengths: Simona is a pretty good lecturer and definitely cares about her students. If you had farina for 110, Simona is more structured in her teaching and expect a bit more day-to-day work. Also Simona is a LIGHTNING FAST grader which was much appreciated--usually you would get your tests back a few hours after they were submitted. 

Weaknesses: BEWARE THERE ARE 3 ORAL PRESENTATIONS YOU HAVE TO DO THAT ARE NOT ON THE SYLLABUS. It was really frustrating to have the presentations just randomly dropped on us with little foresight, especially when you have a heavy course-load. Also Simona did not tell us explicitly what your grade is on the presentations, so that part of your grade is kinda up in the air. They are not too complicated, (usually like 5 mins talking about your hometown or a part of Italy) but were a tad bit annoying and definitely the most boring part of the class was presentations at the beginning of classes. Also the Temi (essays) were a tad bit annoying to do weekly but it is intro lang at Yale so it's par for the course.

Weakness: 
internet problems 
Strengths: 
the professor
the textbook 
a strongly encouraged to speak and practice Italian

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Break out rooms with clear goals (questions to answer from a reading or conversation prompts provided) were excellent.
It went ok.

I thought that the online class style was still super engaging because of frequent break out rooms and mandatory class participation even when not in break out rooms! awesome at adapting to online, overall!

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would definitely recommend this course to any student wishing to learn Italian.
Yes, I think this course is great if you want to learn Italian.
yes! great professor and gives you very useful skills if you ever want to speak, write, or read in Italian

Yes, I think that Simona is a very good lecturer in the Italian department and if you made it thru 110, 120 with Simona is not too bad. However, BEWARE THERE ARE 3 ORAL PRESENTATIONS YOU HAVE TO DO THAT ARE NOT ON THE SYLLABUS. This is mentioned but not explicitly stated on the mock schedule on the syllabus and they are really annoying to do last minute. The presentations are packed into the first 2-2.5 months of the class and are a bit time-consuming, not to mention it's hard to be graded for your speaking with only a semester of a language under your belt. That all said, Simona is definitely a kind person and a solid prof--she's from Italy and drops little tid-bits hear and there in class about italian culture and makes sure to foster a pretty laid-back class environment.
If you want to take Italian, this is a good course to take.
I would recommend this course. If you love Italian food and culture, you'll love the language.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Some asynchronous portions for viewing films and crafting responses to bring to class.
